awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Holography, Quantum Information, and Elliptic Relativity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes two programs of research that explore issues in string theory and classical and quantum gravity with close connections to other areas of physics,especially quantum information theory and particle and nuclear physics:

a) A study of the thermal and statistical physics of holographic systems, and quantum gravity more generally, through the lens of quantum information theory; adressing aspects of the deconfinement phase transition and of entanglement entropy, and fluctuation-dissipation ratios, in time-dependent systems. These issues are important for understanding the process of thermalization in strongly-coupled media such as the quark-gluon plasma.
 
b) Continuing the development of practical, general methods for numerically solving the elliptic Einstein equation to find static, stationary, and Euclidean metrics for higher-dimensional black holes and compactification spaces. Such solutions play an important role in both formal and phenomenogical aspects of string theory, in related mathematical issues, and in holographic models of condensed-matter, fluid, and nuclear physics.

Broader impacts: Undergraduate research is an integral part of both research programs. Three outreach, mentoring, and physics education activities are also included: TheoryNet is an NSF-funded program in which high-energy physicists visit high-school science classrooms. The PI is participating, and proposes to include postdocs and graduate students in addition to professors. The Brandeis Science Posse Program is a leadership program for science-oriented undergraduates from underprivileged backgrounds, which uses focused training and mentoring strategies. The PI will contribute to both the training and the mentoring aspects. The PI plans to adapt teaching strategies based on interaction and peer instruction to the graduate level, develop assessment tools, and perform a controlled experiment comparing the new methods to conventional lecture-based ones in a graduate quantum-mechanics course.

por.por_cntn:
This project had two principal outcomes, the first in research and the second in outreach.

The project's research outcome consisted of a fuller and deeper understanding of the structure of entanglement in quantum field theories, especially holographic ones. Quantum field theories are the language of theoretical physics, and achieving a better understanding of them will help advance research in several areas, including condensed-matter physics, particle physics, and quantum gravity. Holographic quantum field theories are ones that admit a dual description in terms of a higher-dimensional gravitational theory. Holographic field theories typically have a large number of strongly-interacting fields, making them difficult to analyse by traditional methods.

Entanglement is a key feature of quantum mechanics in which different parts of a system are correlated despite the system being in a definite (or pure) state. It turns out that entanglement provides a new and very fruitful lens through which to view quantum field theories. The amount of entanglement between different regions of space in a given state of a given theory is often quantified by the so-called "entanglement entropy".

This project has investigated entanglement and entanglement entropy in a variety of quantum field theories, ranging from free theories to holographic ones. For free theories, new methods of calculation were developed and new insights obtained from them. For example, by looking at dual pairs of free theories in 1+1 dimensions, where the duality is very well understood, it was shown that the entanglement entropy is invariant under duality, clarifying several confusing statements in the literature.

Holographic theories are particularly fascinating because of their connection to general relativity. Through this connection, by studying general relativity, new insights were gained about entanglement entropies in these theories. In particular, strong new evidence was gained for a longstanding conjecture (by Hubeny, Rangamani, and Takayanagi) relating entanglement entropies in such theories to the areas of certain surfaces in the gravitational description. A new way of understanding entanglement in such theories, involving so-called "bit threads", was also proposed.

The other principal outcome of this project involved outreach to high-school students. The PI visited physics classes in several high schools around the greater Boston area, and discussed exciting developments in modern physics, including string theory and black holes, as well as educational pathways and careers in science. For many of those students, this was their first exposure to a real-life working scientist, and to the concept of a career as a scientist.
